text: Awesome. Bold roasty aromas with sweet bitterness and hints of oak. Chocolate and rich. Very dark and full.

Bottle. It poured a black color with a tan head. The aroma was of bourbon, coffee and some wood. The taste was similar to the aroma with more bourbon, coffee, licorice, chocolate and a real nice boozy finish. This was tasty.

Mycket kraftig, brödtung doft. Aning köttig och rejält tung med lätta alkoholinslag. Kaffe och melass 
Tät, silkeslen brygd som är totalt svart, förmodligen den svartaste öl av de tusentals jag sett. En tunn hinna skum. 
Sötma, soja, rund chokladsmak som balanseras mot sälta och en lätt syra. Kaffetoner spelar med.
Poured virtually black with a small beige ring. Aroma of dark chocolate, coffee grinds, roast malt, liquorice. Full body, flavour of the aroma, vanilla smoothness, nicely bitter.
At Hopishop 2016. Aroma of malt, coffee and licorice. Taste has licorice, coffee, sweet soft roasted malt and cream. Liked it more than most other licorice beers.
Bottle - Deep dark big chocolate and cocoa. Deep jet brown with a rich light brown head. Rich dark chocolate, some roast and light booze and a long rich finish.

Pours black with a thick light tan head. Aroma is dark dried fruits, leather and deep creamy malts. Taste is smooth smooth mocha followed very quickly by dried raisiny goodness and a coffee inspired bitter finish. Awesome!

Brewed Oct. 2015: When they say black ale, they aint kidding. If its not pure black its a deep, dark brown. Massive sheet of cardboard brown lace. 

The aroma is pungent black licorice, dates, plums, sour raisins. The oak is beautiful and mercifully mild; an accent. German chocolate. Dusty hazelnut. I love the complexity and the flavor of this beer. 

The flavor is a burst of alcohol, followed by a blast of burnt oak. Then there is a cascade of licorice, dark cherry, plum and dates. The alcohol coats the tongue.

The feel is creamy and milky, but dry like Ovaltine. It burns just a bit on the way down. It is a superior dark ale. The alcohol and flavor of a stout with the smooth edges of a porter.
Pours a brown almost black color with a small tan head. Aromas heavy on chocolate/coffee with some smoke. Nice bitterness mixed with the coffee/chocolate flavors. Excellent porter.

If youre thinking about having more than a couple of beers you may want to share this bottle with a friend. Though its quite filling, its high ABV is well masked by dark roasted coffee character. Dark, heavy aromas match the mocha colored head.
Pours deep dark brown for the bottle. Dark brown initially to off beige head. Aromas of chocolate, vanilla, slight booze. Huge chocolate throughout, nice finish. Unbelievably easy at 13%. Solid brew

0,75l bottle at Vienna Tasting shared by Nische, big thanks. BB 04/18/11. black color, small off-white head. smells of vanilla, licorice, spices, some roast. too much vanilla. full body, soft carbonation, slick mouthfeel. tastes of licorice, vanilla, spices, wood, rather alcoholic. finishes lightly roasted with some alcohol with notes of licorice and wood. good stuff, a bit too much vanilla for me. overall ok.
Bottle at the Vienna tasting February 2016. Many thanks! Almost black colour. Lots and lots of dark chocolatey coffeeish roasted flavours. Very rich and full bodied. Very tasty, very good. Excellent.
Bottle kindly shared by Nische, many thanks. Very dark brown color with medium beige head. Chocolate, dark malt, hazelnuts in aroma. Taste, chocolate, coffee, vanilla, biscuits, hazelnuts. Tasty.

Bottle from systembolaget. Shared in Vienna. Pitch black with off white head. Chocolately aroma with light vanilla. Lightly roasted. Chocolate and light boozy. Light boozy, chocolately flavor with syrup, coffee, roast, milk chocolate and molasses. Strong flavors and nicely balanced.

Flaska bishops Örebro. Mörkbrun nästan svart kulör. Doft av knäck, choklad, vanilj och fat. I smak känns torkad frukt, rostad malt, mjölkchoklad, fat och vanilj. Skön kolsyrehalt och fin rund avslutning
UPDATED: MAY 20, 2016 Flaska från Bishop Örebro. Frisk och mustig på samma gång. Frisk smak av kakao, portvin, mjölkchoklad. Smutsig svart. Doft av portvin.

This beer is complex and yet so easy to drink. It has so many notes it could write an opera. Share this with a good friend and you won't regret it.

Had at Gordon Ramsay pub in Vegas. 22 oz bottle. Strong hands of black licorice balanced with roasted mall.

Very smooth and very strong. Also very nice. I think I could drink this until I passed out. Shame it comes in 6oz pours.

Bottle (750 ml). Pours opaque black with thick, dark tan head and substantial lacing. (No light gets through the beer.) Oak, alcohol, and licorice nose. Sweet roasted malt upfront followed by licorice and some chocolate with a hint of coffee. Long finish.

Black pour from draft at whole foods. Sweet and spicy. A little cocoa burn. Nice beer. Strong.

16/X/15 - 50cl bottle from Bierhalle Deconinck (Vichte) @ home - BB: n/a (2015-1496) Thanks to PriorL for sharing the bottle!
Clear dark purple brown beer, small aery beige head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: sweet, caramel, roasted malts, sweet, hint of green banana, alcohol. MF: soft carbon, full body. Taste: sourish start, lemony touch, caramel, malty, bitter hops. Aftertaste: bit sourish, lots of chocolate, bitter hops, alcohol, sourish, caramel, overripe banana, cocoa powder, coffee notes. Nice one!

From old notes.
Beautiful pour. Long lucious glossy black forming a complex ultra easy beige head. Beautiful intregration of dark chocolate, light liquorice and roast into a stylish whole without losing each individual element.

Small brown head over deep-brown beer. Alcohol, hint at ureum, black chocolate, mocha, dark but sweet grains; generally smelling sweet. Sweet going over to dry-ish bitterness via quite some liquorice. Again chocolate, both black and sweet one. Full-bodied feel, alcoholwarmth, very slick, viscous, oozy, chewy; carbonation gone. Sweet, but good Porter.  Thanks to the bringers of gifts ans purveyors of rare items!

Blackity black. Tan foamy head, spotty lace. Leather rich aroma, dark chocolate, tobacco, dark roast rich. Taste is rich malt dark , roast chocolate, ashy smoke, raison molasses, maple maybe, nice very nice, aged a few years I believe. Rich sweet syrupy, anise.

Thanks to ElManana+1! 750 ml. bottle sampled @ Tims orgasmic Trillium tasting. Good sized sample. Black, small head. Nose is light weird mushroom note, touch umami, roasted herbs & basic milk chocolate sweetness. Taste is interesting roasted note upfront, umami, sugar, melted cheap chocolate, milk chocolate which starts to dominate more in the palate as you drink more of it, faint herbal note. Creamy chocolate body. Bit quirky but as you get more accustomed to it, it just becomes more like drink, sweet, cheap & nice chocolate. Rather liked it. Nice beer.
Bottle at tderoeck's place. Creamy, thIck, chocolate, vanilla, very nice. Lovely!

Huge imperial Stout, heavy smoked chocolate caramel, starting sweet with slightly heavier carbonation, turning to slightly roasty coffee with little bitterness. 13.2% ABV? Not very detectable. Lovely Stour, high on my list.
750ml from Elise shared at a tasting. Deep viscous licorice Imperial Stout. Heavy, but kind of straightforward. Gets more monstrous as you sip at it. Heavy molasses tones. intense.
Tap at draft and vessel in Milwaukee. Black with thick tan head. Powerful nose. Sweet malt coffee taste with licorice. Heavy alcohol and nice sweetness. Big beer and a good one.
Big chocolate and a touch of vanilla. Big roast. Average consistency. Average carbonation. Bitter finish. Pours black with mocha head and lacing. Pretty good stuff. Tap at Snallygaster.
Draft pour at Snallygaster. Dark brownish black with light tan head. Aromas of smoke, chocolate. Tastes of licorice, chocolate, roast. Medium-full body with a dry finish.
Pours jet black, with a long lasting darkish tan head. Aroma of alcohol, wood, and malt. Taste is rich and smooth, notes of oak and chocolate. Slightly sweet. A very nice brew, thumbs up.

Tap tonight at Cask and Vine for the distributor showdown.
Blacker than a quad should be. Rich fruit some roasty malt and subtle oaky bourbon notes. Very stout like but very tasty.
Lumipyryyn ja pakkaseen. Marraskuu ja kaljakori. Tumma kun piru. Kannatti raahata. From Jackson.
Pours black with chocolate head. Aroma and flavor are of chocolate, caramel, and nuts. Heavy on alcohol, but quite drinkable. Pairs well with berries or cherries.
Wow what an amazing beer! Flavor is easy to judge and is a smoky chocolate with an amazingly smooth aftertaste.
-pours black with a brown head that laces. Aroma is rich dark malt-chocolate/cocoa, wood, raisin/plum. Taste is rich dark malt-chocolate/cocoa/molasses, wood/earthy hops, slight alcohol.

Mahogany trimmed black body with with tall frothy-smooth khaki head falling to a solid ring, dots and thin peninsulas of lace

Aromas and flavors of caramel, peanut butter, pecan, chocolate, vanilla, juicy dark fruit, cherry with accents of citrus and marshmallow, flowing vinous notes, undertones of treacle and molasses with a mild spirit character warming on a silky smooth medium body with a clean creamy texture, flavorful, smoothly fading residuals of the previously mentioned components

750 ml cork and cage bottled on 12/05/14 served at 50° into Riedel Swirl Red Wine
Bottle share thanks to Homer. Black pour with tan head. Aroma is super rich, chocolate, molasses, mild coffee. Taste is chocolate, rich, decadent, think mouthfeel. Really tasty.

Bottle to taster. A super rich and decadent chocolate and molasses and toffee aroma with a light hop grassiness. Pitch black in color, minimal head. Taste is a dark chocolate bitterness followed by cocoa powder and mousse. Really damn good. Minimal warming.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours jet black with tiny to no beige head. No lacing. Aroma is of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, alcohol, ashes, licorice, dark fruits. Taste is of coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, licorice. Palate: Full bodied. Creamy texture, sweet. Sticky on the lips. Light carbonation. Overall: Nice beer. Coarse.

Bottle (750 ml). Shared by czar, thanks! Split with the Québec crew.

Appearance: Pitch black with a medium beige head, poor retention and little to no lacing. 

Aroma: Black licorice is the main feature here along ashes, raisins, roasted malts, smoke and chocolate. 

Taste: Moderately sweet with black liquorice taking most of the place again along ashes, smokey malts, caramel, roasted malts, toasted notes and alcohol.

Palate: Full body. Moderate carbonation. Warming finish. Lingering black licorice aftertaste. 

Overall: Take this rating with a grain of salt as I profoundly hate black licorice in beer. I can see why people usually like this as theres a wide variety of flavors and nothing is "off", but the black licorice being the main flavor here make this one completely unbalanced (it overshadow everything else) and very hard to drink for me, plus its also quite boozy. I naturally wasnt able to finish my glass. On a purely hedonist scale, this one would rank near the bottom for me, but I can recognize this isnt a bad beer per se.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2015 Bottle shared by czar, thanks bro! Pours a medium black with no head and no lacing. Nose is of alcohol, ash, roasted malt and nuts. Taste is moderately sweet, roasted, a bit hot and moderately bitter. Some black licorice. Body is full, carbonation light to moderate and I cant see myself drinking more than a tiny glass of this. Overall this was just OK, worth a try.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2015 pours unclear dark brown with a reviving beige cap, some retention and lacing. fragrant spicy licorice and bourbon, charred and gently smoked maltiness - fair amount of cocoa, molasses sweetness, coffee and cream, clean. light carbonation, medium to full body - oily; boozy and sweet licorice-tannic-spicy finish. very nice spicy and tasty stuff.

Excellent stuff. Warm and boozy, slick and slippery. This one is all over the board in aroma and taste; pit fruit, licorice, molasses..... The ABV will do you in however, part of the appeal. An excellent to a session.

Had in a sniffer poured from 750ml bottle. Pours pitch black beer with a thick brown head. Flavor is very chocolatey, ALCOHOL, but with a sweet kick.
Amazing taste with a warming sensation, carful this one take you to another planet.

Opaque, little lace. 
Very full body, dense flavor, smooth and rich mouthfeel, hot, long palate, tasty finish. 
Sweet but balanced by bitter background. 
Roast flavors, coffee, vanilla essence. 
Wonderful, could pass as a stout. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black with brown head. Smells caramel, syrup and coffee malts. Feels rich creamy with decent carbonation in mouth. Tastes dark chocolate, coffee, light roasts, syrup. High alcohol content leaves it's after taste behind. A good stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Color dark brown with medium brown head. Aroma chocolate, roasted malty. Taste roasted, liqourice, malt, dark chocolate.

750 ml bottle. Pours black with a beautiful dark tan head. You get coffee, sweet malt, star anise, and hint of chocolate on the nose. Tastes of chocolate, roasted malts, raisins, plums, hops, and a little coffee and some sweet citrus. Nice and complex with a medium body. It looks and smells like a stout, but drinks like a porter. Excellent brew. Definitely best Ive had from Uinta.

Sweet, chocolate, dark caramel, dark fruit malty aroma. Malty flavor: Sweet, coffee, black licorice, dark caramel, raisin. Nice character from the barrel; prominent, but not too much. Some pepper spiciness. Drier finish. Nice creamy mouthfeel.
Any description of this beer would come painfully short of the overall quality of this Quad Black Ale. Just go get one, and see exactly why its loved by many.

Purchased earlier today from Cigarette City. $10.99 for the 750 mL bottle. To short-stemmed white wine glass, it pours a mahogany-tinted taupe with which a webby Tuscan beige head 1½ fingers in length stood. Aromas of young-matured port wine, black currant purée, wild black cherries, burnt spelt pie crusts, grill char, 70% dark chocolate, wood pulp, candied walnuts, black licorice candies, vanilla beans, bourbon oak, pipe tobacco, and London ale yeast. Tastes the same with the addition of dried lavender, white sage/herbal hops, damp newspaper, and roasted soy beans. Abrasive, but in a fittingly good way. At 13.2% abv, youd think this would be your last beer, but the content is hidden so ridiculously well, that I could probably sip one other bottle of this before genuinely feeling its effects. Full-bodied, but you couldve guessed that.
Shared bottle. Pours black with a nice tan head. Aroma of chocolate, malt, dark fruit, and wood. Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate, dark fruit, caramel, and oak. Very nice.
(bottle 31/12-2014) low brown head, black color, chocolate roasted taste, soft co2, rather complex taste. BB date 03/19/1x.

This beer pours a deep black color with a thick, creamy brownish/tan head. Aroma is of oak, coffee and chocolate. Mouth feel is thick and creamy. Taste is amazing. Notes of molasses, chocolate, coffee, dark fruit and oak. Pour then let sit for 10 minutes to warm a little. Flavors are out of control. Amazing beer. Would LOVE to have this on tap.

On tap at at Oscars Alehouse in Eldersburg, MD. Opaque, near black with a brown head and excellent lacing. Aroma of licorice, molasses, roasted malt, chocolate, dark fruit, alcohol and oak. Taste of licorice, alcohol burn, chocolate, roasted malt, molasses, dark fruit, tobacco and charred wood. Medium/full body and medium carbonation. Complex and excellent, but the alcohol is all too obvious. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle (bottled 09/2013). Pours black with a dark beige head. Black licorice dominates the aroma, dark chocolate and some alcohol present. Medium-full bodied. Creamy, followed by a significant bitterness and light chalkiness.

Bottle. Thick black pour, thick tan head. Aroma of licorice, chocolate, molasses, roasted malts, some soy sauce, roasted malts and slightly spicy. Flavor is quite bitter, roasted and somewhat sweet. Huge body and very well balanced. Nice brew.

Bottle at the parentals with my dad. Pour is pitch black with a frothy brown head and great lacing. Big chocolatey, roasty, brown sugar, caramelized sugars, some tobacco, grapey, somewhat oaky, and leathery aroma. Taste is huge leather, tobacco, roasted malt, big cocoa notes, coffee, somewhat nutty, licorice, soy sauce, and lightly smoky with slightly bitter finish. Full mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Pretty tasty.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2014 2011 Vintage - 750 ml bottle - Aromas of coffee, chocolate, oak and dark malt. Palate of figs, licorice, roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Big flavors and big nose. Alcohol very well hidden. Time has been kind to this beer. Have to get more and cellar. Not much oak here, but perhaps time has mellowed that. Damn good beer nevertheless. Great on cold winter night by the fire with some dark chocolate truffles.

Bottled 5/14/14. Pitch black, thin dark brown head. Smell is dark fruit, raisin, molasses, toast, wood, licorice. Taste is smoky, dark, creamy and rich, bitter smoked/beef jerky aftertaste. Slight carbonation; long, drying aftertaste with significant warming.

Poured from the bottle into my Samuel Adams glass at 57.5F. The pour produced a volatile head of milk-chocolate colored foam, requiring separate pours to fill the glass. The body of the ale is pitch black. The aroma is strong with burnt oak and alcohol. Medium to thick mouthfeel, with very little in the way of carbonation. A rich, sweet beer, with strong, bitter coffee notes, that linger long after the initial tasting. This black ale should be enjoyed with a contrasting edible, as the bitterness can be a little overpowering at times. While high in alcohol content, the burn only asserts itself at the end of the sip. This beer appeals to my tastes for rich, dark beers, and will receive continued consideration. Good job, SLC!

Bottle sample at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks beerandbeyond. Pours opaque black with a brown head, aroma of wood, coconut, vanilla, caramel, whiskey, brandy, flavor of wood, vanilla, whiskey, coconut, chocolate and brandy, medium to full bodied. Great
Bottle. Pours black with deep tan head. Aroma is very chocolate, winey, rich, vanilla, raisin, dark fruit. Taste is full bodied, very rich, desserty, smooth, silky. Overall, very good.

Poured from bottle to glass. Dark hue with fizzy brown head that settled to a ring. Aroma is licorice, plum, chocolate, red wine, ethanol. Mouthfeel is great with a full body and crisp carbonation. Taste is sweet with a roasted astringent following and ethanol finish. Overall this is a really nice brew.

Bottle: 2010 Vintage: Served in a taster:
Pitch black with a brown lacing.
Aroma of roast, some coffee, liquorice, some mocha, wood, light bourbon/whiskey notes, deep and complex, very nice!
Flavours of liquorice, dark chocolate, light bourbon/whiskey tones, some vanilla and wood, roast, roasted malts, light coffee tones, bitters, dried raisin, thick, easy but complex, fucking tasty!

text: 750 ml bottle. Pours a thick, solid black with a large 4 inch dark brown head that lasts. Taste is of roasted malt, coffee, caramel, hops, pine, citrus, resin, chocolate, liquorice and wood. Similar aroma. Has a full body, with a bitter and dry finish. Doesnt come across as a 13% abv beer. There are a lot of levels to the flavors that last with each sip. Very easy to drink, quite enjoyable and well worth having again. Mine was 5 months old, I will find some to age and have again.

Pours black with a thick lasting brown head. Bourbon, coffee and wood aroma. Taste has notes of chocolate, licorice, and mincemeat pie. Finish is long and boozy. Throat burning. This beer is phenomenal.

Pours an opaque, extremely dark brown with a thick, well-retaining brown head. Dark roasted and smoky malt on the nose. BBQd meat and a little bourbon as well. Thick, invasive, and large in the palate. Sweet, cherry, smoky, then bitter. Burnt ends of a BBQd brisket. Very exciting brew.
For a beer that pushes 14% alcohol, this one has some of the smoothest flavor I have ever had. If you are lucky enough to come across this beer, do yourself a favor and get it.

"lots of BIG flavors and scents going on here, especially roast, licorice, coffee, chocolate, (slight)vanilla...and a surprisingly mellow barrel aspect for a beer of such strength. got this on sale and am glad I did. Really nice and one ill likely revisit without any other beers before or after. nice feel, smooth and full, not cloying, and while strong, hides the abv quite well.

This dark black beer has a raisin aroma like dried fruit. It has a chocolate flavor but isn't sweet. It's almost like that bitter baking chocolate but it balanced and smooth. Bitterness is subtle. Really good beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle sample at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks beerandbeyond. Black with tan head. A little anis, a little smoke and a little roast in the nose, a little sweetish, rich bitterness. Roasty finish, full body, no carbonation and hints of licorice.
If You want it dark, try this labyrinth. You will find your way into darkness... With a good chocolate taste when You get in and a soft molasses exit

Poors black, slight reddish hue. Poors thick reddish brown. Can smell the oak barrels before it hits the nose. Strong mouthful, slight booziness. Sits on the pallet with a little more bitterness then I would have liked. Overall, good beer though.

Bottle sample at American Strong Ale tasting at Beer&Beyond, Tel Aviv. 2012 edition. Very dark black with quickly diminishing brown head. Aroma of coconut, vanilla, noted of coffee. Flavor of coconut, vanilla, licorice, very sweet, a bit bitter, balanced. Oily texture. Full body. Sweet aftertaste. Very good.

Im reviewing this beer rodeo cool. At this point the booze has settled into the nose, masking what were hints of dark fruits, rasins, leather and anis. On the palate the alcohol is less noticeable and the flavors masked on the nose start to shine. The lightly bitter tannins play with the fruitier overtones if the beer. This doesnt last for long as the spiciness takes over leading to a drier finish than expected.

Bottle shared by friends. Aroma is mainly molasses, roast, some chocolate, oak, vanilla. Pours a sexy black with a big mocha head. Flavor is medium oak, roasted notes, chocolate, espresso, some anise. Good stuff.Pretty heavy but not over the top.

Bottle sample at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks beerandbeyond. Black with a light brown head. Lovely aroma of roast, dark chocolate, a bit of espresso and a bit of oak. Rather sweet flavor with roast, dark chocolate, a bit of licorice in the back, a coffee note and a bit of alcohol. Full-bodied. Very good.

From a bottle shared by jheath99. Pours black with a thin, light brown head. Smells like strong alcohol and chocolate syrup. Tastes like alcohol, dark chocolate, and burnt toast. Medium body and low carbonation.

Bottle shared by jheath99. Pours opaque black with creamy tan head. Aroma is chocolate malts, light roast, espresso, light raisins and prunes, light smoke, light alcohol spice, and light earthiness. Flavor is rich chocolate and espresso notes, light ash, medium earthy bitterness, and faint dark fruit esters; dry finish with chocolate and roast notes lingering. Medium body and carbonation.

Pours a jet black with a thick tan head. Aroma is of nice roasty malts, coffee minus the bitterness, chocolate, and subtle licorice notes if you really search for it. Taste is of medium bitterness and a hidden amount of booziness despite the 13.2% abv. Absolutely a must have. Paired well with chocolate cake.

A massive brew. Not for beginners and not for yuppies, its the real deal. This brew will ruin you. At 13.2% abv it is no damn joke. It will tear you apart. It pours dark, nearly black, It smells like hades. It bites like hades. This is no joke, and forget you newbies, it will roll your heads. Its excellent, and deserves an A just because it will kick your ass fast. This brew is insane, take extreme caution.

Excellent beer. Lacy frothy head. Strong coffee aroma and booze. Smooth wash down. Full bodied. Feels like it has been aged. Definitely a sipping beer on a cool night or at the tail end of an evening. Tasty. Delicious. Nice.

Black with tan head, is retained well, nice legs and lacing. Smell is licorice and caramel. Dark chocolate and licorice taste, marshmallow-like mouthfeel. Long finish, only time the alcohol is noticeable.

Black pour with small brown head. Thick, light carbonation. Big aromas of roasted malts, slight licorice, chocolate. The taste is like the aroma, big and rich, warming alcohol, but not overwhelming. I didnt know what to expect with this one and was very pleasantly surprised. Awesome beer.

Very dark brown to black color with a brown head. The aroma has some strong chocolate and licorice notes, as well as some heavy sugar notes. The flavor is similar. I get some heavy chocolate notes as well as some ashy, roasted malt notes. There is also a hint of licorice as well as some oak. Thick mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

A very nice, smooth black. Pours very thick black with a beautiful brown head. Smells of coffee, chocolate and licorice. Taste has lots of coffee and licorice, with a sweet finish. For 13%, not too boozy. Paired with fig pizza, some of the booze comes out, with a bit more milkiness.

Super carbonated. Big head the color of chocolate milk. Jet black body. Licorice, toffee, chocolate syrup. Medium heavy body feel (stoutish). Strong licorice flavor, very smokey, woody, slightly oaky, harsh, boozy. Sugar, sweet, chocolate, coffee bean. Complex.

750 ml corked and caged bottle courtesy of and shared with beastmaster. Pours pitch black with a massive creamy dark brown head. Aroma of sweet dark fruits, smokey roast, anise/black licorice, some strong chocolate coming through, char maybe from barrels. Smells pretty rich. Flavor is sweet and smokey molasses, chocolate, oak, booze, raisins. Medium plus plus body, medium to low carbonation, and very smooth. Warming. Very sticky here. Sort of like smoked chocolate covered licorice sticks. Jury is still out but a nice dessert in small quantities. Drinkability on the low side but overall nice.

Aroma is mostly chocolate, licorice and oak. Pours dark brown, tan head that holds for some time. Taste chocolate, coffe, oak, alcohol. Its a bit too alcohol forward .. well at 13.2%, and Im sure its actually more, you cant really have that against it. Overall very solid quad.

Pours a deep dark with a tan head that dies off to a thin lacing, the aroma is Chocolate, coffee, caramel, roasty the taste is coffee, chocolate, dark fruits, creamy mouth feel with some citrus and smooth finish with lingering warmth from the alcohol.

Very black with a brownish head. Aroma of wood, roast, chocolate, licorice. Taste is rich bitter chocolate with a substantial woodiness and some fruit-like sweetness. Full bodied and creamy smooth. Nice.

Bottle @ grill event, with Mads and Lukas. Pitch black, medium tan head that settles nicely, nice lacing. Aroma, roasted malts, coffee, liquorice, dark chocolate, burnt sugar, molasses, oak, little alcohol, vanilla. Taste, roasted malts, dark chocolate, coffee, liquorice, oak, vanilla sweetness, burnt sugar. Bitter roasted aftertaste. Slightly oily mouth feel.

Bottle. Pours black, light brown head. Aroma is coffee, dark chocolate, oak, some sweet vanilla. Burnt sugar? Taste dark chocolate, licorice, sweet with fresh bitter finish. Warming alcohol, but well hidden. Nice beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Reviewed from notes and perhaps the best brew Ive had by date from this company.
The night I had this, I poured this into a pint glass and a snifter.
The appearance was a pure jet black color with a one finger white foamy head in both glasses. The lacing was the same in both glasses as it was fairly clingy and thick.
The smell was a roasted barley and coffee that combines with a black licorice that ends up allowing a decent roasted chocolate coming about to balance it all out. Wow, what a nice complex smell to this.
The taste was bitter, roasty and sweet at different times and ends up allowing these super nice qualities to come back in the aftertaste. There is a finish and its somewhat dry and sweet.
On the palate, this one is not sessionable by any means. It sits heavy on the body with a decent carbonation running about my mouth and tongue.
Overall, American Black Ale, wow, this is a very well done beer for its style and for me.

750mL bottles on 3/29/13. Beautiful pour, reminiscent of Expedition. Palate is right on par as well. Warming alcohol, but well hidden, and smooth as frack. Nice black licorice, moderately fruity, burnt flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

With a medium-dark brown, almost orange-esque head, this black ale looks serious, roasted, strong, and requiring of your respect. The nose is roasted, yes, with heavy, syrupy sweetness that smells like its standing up to the roast. It tastes like an imperial stout, but with a twist. Fruity notes with sugar, and perhaps a whiff of heated corn sugar. Yes, it is serious. Yes, it is roasted, and beyond those strong characters its hard to detect much else (other than that fruity, sugary stuff). Cool.
Pours like motor oil with no head. Heavy porter with heavy flavor and a strong taste of licorice. Very sweet beer and a little boozy.

750 ml bottle from Premier Gourment. Pours a oily black with creamy brown head. Aroma is very roasty and full of rich dark fruits, cocoa, black licorice and some gentle woodiness. Flavour is huge and rich with lost of roastiness, big on the licorice, some prune/date and chocolate and a bit of oakiness. Slick mouthfeel. Very impressive.

Sampled at AC Beerfest 2014. Poured a pitch black color with a huge frothy dark mocha colored head. Aroma of rich caramel, dark chocolate, and dark roasted malts. Taste of dark fruit, rich dark chocolate, roasted malt, and caramel.
Bottle from Lazy Dog. Aroma of coffee and flora. Taste of roasted coffee and a hint of flora. Heavy bodied. Sweet aftertaste.

Really nice sample pour of motor oil color with red head. Nose is roasted and mild licorice. Sweetish. Flavor is rich and caramel roasted malt. Enjoyable and smooth for 13 percent. Not a bad drink but a little heavy for me...

Poured at tasting. Fairly close to black with a mocca head and lace. Aroma was a wonderful chocolate, prune, licorice. The aroma seemed thick and begged to be savored itself. The taste was chocolate, a little coffee with the late sip and finish being licorice as the alcohol warmed. Oily and slick. This was fantastic.
It blacks out the light when you hold it up, with a balding head. Big fig dried fruit aromas. Sweet big fuzzy leather with a viscosity like motor oil. Big and boastful with no apologies.
Dark draft pour. Barrel aged flavor with chocolate, vanilla, and maybe a tiny bit of cherry. Very complex. Sweet finish. Very well hidden alcohol. Very smooth and drinkable. Loved it.
One of the nicest surprises of the Hunahpu fest...a surprise only in that I was surprised to see it! Absolutely fantastic brew...I savored the entire pour.

Pours black with no head. Swirling it leaves oily lacerations. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, booze, muscovado sugar, honey. Taste is muscovado sugar, coffee, dark chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, slight liqourice. Mouthfeel is oily and sticky with no carbonation. Aftertaste is muscovado sugar, honey, bourbon.

750 ml corked and caged bottle, bottled on 1/23/13, a little over 13 months ago. Pours pitch black with a large dark tan head with great retention. Aroma is chocolaty, licorice, molasses, wood, coconut. Taste is sweet and savory with a strong licorice flavor. Mouthfeel is oily, body thick and chewy. A very nice and masterful beer, but I find myself steering away from these big dark heavy brews lately. A year or two ago, I would have given this a much higher score.

Bottle at THT. Pours pitch black. Aroma is coffee, grassy notes, some chocolate, bit licorice and roast. Taste is moderate sweet and quite bitter. Boozey, lots of alcohol in the finish along with coffee. Full bodied, oily texture and just lovely.

Bottle @ Dean to Mouth tasting, courtesy of Benzai. Pours a black beer with a small, brownish head on top. Aroma of roasted malts, bourbon and wood. Flavor is very sweet, cloying sweetness. Big alcoholic sweetness going on, but balanced a bit by some barrel characters. Round, well balanced beer. Lovely stuff.

Deep dark brown with a tan, lacy lasting frothy head. Smells of deep roast with chocolate, deep sweet malt, and a raisin. A bit of bourbon. Full oily silk body. Amazing. Tastes of sweet chocolate with malt, nice roast, raisin, with a hint of alcohol, lots of roast with a smooth barley taste. An excellent brew and the best of this evening.
Sampled from bottle @ The Hague tasting. Opaque pitch black color, nice light brown head. Smell and taste malts, roasted malts, some hops. Oh lovely lovely. Just lovely.

Bottle at the "Lets celebrate the fact that Dean is already the Mayor of M&S Den Haag even though its only been open for 24 hours tasting!". Poured a dark mahogany with a frothy light tan head. The aroma is rich creamy caramel, toffee, liqourice. The flavour Is strong bitter with a big boozy alcoholic liqourice bitter palate with an oily mouthfeel. Full bodied with flat carbonation.
Bottle @ tasting. Aroma is liquorice, roast, chocolate, molasses, coffee. Flavour is big chocolate, roast, molasses, liquorice etc etc.

Bottle shared at the "Lets celebrate the fact that Dean is already the Mayor of M&S Den Haag even though its only been open for 24 hours tasting!". Pours near black with a beige head. Aroma of fudge, chocolate, caramel, sweet malt, light licorice. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter. Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation.
Poured virtually black with a small beige ring. Aroma of dark chocolate, coffee grinds, roast malt, liquorice. Full body, flavour of the aroma, vanilla smoothness, nicely bitter.

sample @THT courtesy of Benzai.
Thin tan head. Clear black pour. Nice bitterness. Lovely brew

Wow this thing is all over the place but in a very good way. Pours a thick black with a deep tan head. Aroma is full of roasted malts and Belgian candied sugar. Sweet and roasty. Taste bubbles up on your tongue and leads off with a Belgian quad and mid way through shifts with a hint of licorice and into an imperial stout with just a hint of bourbon oak on the finish. Great great stuff.
A malty chocolaty aroma. Dark brown color. A slight smoked/roasted coffee taste with a slight chocolate aftertaste

Bottle from July 2011. Pours thick and black with a caramel brown head. Big chocolate aromas - brownies with chocolate syrup. Also toffee, wood, burnt toast, and slight raisin and dried fig. Taste is roasty, coffee and dark chocolate, wood, toffee, hints of vanilla and cola. Moderate bitterness. Full and smooth palate. A bit of alcohol burn but its mostly felt, not tasted, after sitting in the bottle for 2.5 years. A nice big beer to enjoy slowly.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2017 re-rate 1/17.....my tastes are starting to dislike overly powerful stouts but loooved this.  bumped from 4.0.   was bottled 9/14 so aged awhile.  just soooo  smoooooth.   chocolate is most prevalent in aroma and taste.  some wood, light alcohol.   will be buying several to see fresh vs. aged.  might end up being my favorite porter............................................ favorite style. purch in CO;drank in TX - they now sell in TX!! looks like bottle date is 1/12. High scores b/c it is all I love about this style even if there are a few opportunities. black pour of course; aroma of all things good - wood, alcohol, choc, roast. Taste is a little hot - scary if 2 years didnt tone it down and at times (warmer) it overpowers the other flavors. Still damn good though with flavors like aromas. will have again for sure

From a tight corked 750 ml bottle, dated 8/12/13. Pours black with brown head. Aroma of dark roasted malts, dark chocolate, Medium carbonation and big mouthfeel. Flavors of dark chocolate, milk chocolate, dark roasted malts, Overall a lovely balance of dark roasted malts and rich chocolate with minimal alcohol or off flavors.

This is jet fuel plain and simple. This beer is dark with little licorice. 13.2% alcohol is enough to slay you.

On tap at Zio Carlos Ft. Worth. Pours black and thick with a nice tan head. Big aroma of bourbon, vanilla, and roasted malt. Lots of chocolate, less of the licorice (ok by me), dark roasted coffee. Alcohol is present but finishes easily for 13.2%
Robust, get outta the way, you will get squashed...that is all I have to say! So deal with it!

750 ml - pours almost completely opaque . Roasty bourbon aromas . Some licorice bitterness . Mildly sweet . A really good beer , I'm glad I got to try this one .

Rich malty aroma with a hint of chocolate and very slight burnt malt tones. Dark black in color with a tan head. Rich, deep, complex but not too intense dark malty goodness. Burnt flavor is just barely present and not at all overwhelming. Full bodied luscious velvet mouthfeel. Pairs well with TJs Toscano cheese.

Bottled 07JUN12

Pours inky black with a nice graham toasty top. Smells of malts, chocolate, molasses, brown sugar, whisky and oak come together. Rich mutha. Dark roasted malts, some leather, molasses, dates, dark on dark chocolate, cocoa nibs, coffee and hints of licorice and oak, nice and sweet with a good earthen balance. Thick and viscous, sticky and slick with a warm finish. Nice beer, took me by surprise. Ready to drink as well, I wouldnt age this one.

Serving type: bottle

10-15-2012

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2013 Oily black pour with a tall, creamy mocha brown head that has great retention. Aroma is huge on roast, dark fruit, earth and burnt sugar, the licorice takes a second to come out, but it does so strongly, chocolate, nice woody, toasty oak, a touch of vanilla and boozy notes of Bourbon, Gin and Brown Rum. Definitely a little over boozy in the aroma, but still great. Flavor starts off surprisingly strong with toasted oak and crème brulee-like vanilla notes, then some nice, smooth, but strong roast, a little char and smoke, some dark fruit, nice, chocolate notes, not quite milk chocolate sweet, some planty hop notes, a touch of molasses and pumpkin-like earthy sweetness along with some rum booziness and cocoa to the finish. Thick, heavy, creamy, chewy (might even have a little oat sliminess) palate with a light, but prickly carbonation. Really solid stuff, dangerously smooth and inviting in flavor and aroma for a 13%ABV beer.

Appearance - dark pour. Caramel head. 

Aroma - mild. Licorice 

Mouth - thick and oily. Low carb. 

Taste - very sweet licorice. Very sweet and sugary like molasses. Mild barrel flavor. Long finish. High gravity. 

Overall - not my style. Some love the sweet and this would be great for them. Not me. Too much.

Une belle grosse bouteille embouteillée le 29 mars 2013. Un bière brune très foncée presque noire avec une mousse dense. Un nez emballant allant du chocolat, au grain rôti, au café, au sucre demerera avec une touche fruité. Une bouche onctueuse, amère, où se mêlent une foule de saveur. Une bière forte en alcool qui se laisse boire à grande gorgée. Superbe. Je ne me doutais pas que les Mormons pouvaient faire daussi bonne bière !

Un liquide embouteillé le 29 mars 2013. Une superbe mousse foncée qui fond tranquillement sur une robe de charbon. Je regarde une ravissante et longue traînée de poudre collée sur la paroi de mon verre. Mon nez est rapidement conquis par ce porter impérial qui incorpore à ses notes chocolatées de riches et superbes parfums de vanille rôtie, de mélasse, de bois fruité et de réglisse légèrement salée. Mes papilles adorent la profonde mise en place de malts habilement travaillés. Ma langue raffole du large profil fruité construit par le chêne. Mon palais aime les tapisseries dépices et de réglisse noire. En bouche, voilà une structure admirablement bien montée pour faire durer les flaveurs. Dans ce corps huileux, les bulles, qui sont modérées, sont des accélérateurs de molécules. En fin de parcours, voici lhabile manifestation dun alcool fissuré par des herbes et des grains torréfiés qui se fusionnent pour offrir une savoureuse capacité amère. En conclusion, comme dirait mon pote Johannes Diderik van der Waals, «une ostie de grosse bière nouwère qui torche en sacrament».

750 mL bottle. Black in color with a large tightly packed tan head. Aroma is of licorice, dark sipping chocolate, brown sugar, vanilla and light coffee. Taste is emanating licorice, vanilla, nice oaky notes, roasted malts, and dark chocolate. Velvety smooth.
Bottle. The look is black in color, big tan head, and dark. The smell is licorice, oak, roast, malts, and toasted coconut. The taste is nice, malty, big alcohol, barrel, and tasty. Good feel.

13.2%?!? Wow, totally missed that, though it helps explain how we ended up so drunk that night. The tall Scotch nightcap probably didnt help. Surprisingly this black ale pours black. Aroma and taste of chocolate, caramel, licorice and charred wood.
On tap at square burger. Ps black with a thin tan head. The aromas are dark chocolate, roast coffee. The mouthful is dry, roasty and bitter with a big body and light carbonation. Great beer!
750 bottle pours dark black with a small tan head. not much nose. Taste of sweet chewiness, some chocolate, chalk, not much barrel , and lots of alcohol.

text: Dark brown, tan head. Medium body, medium duration. Smooth chocolate, coffee, cookie taste. Licorice, malt, lots of alcohol smell. Lots of ABV but not that noticeable when you drink it. It has a sting too it when you sip it like taking a shot of whiskey.

First on tap at Mikkeller Bar in San Fran. Second time from a bomber purchased in San Diego.
Poured from a bomber into a snifter glass very black with a thick tan had that dissipates into a nice lacing.
Aroma of nice bittersweet chocolate, booze, caramel vanilla
Nice balance of sweetness with malty wonder. A nice syrupy brew that is one I am happy to visit again & again.

750 ml bottle into snifter, bottled on 6/8/2011. Pours dense pitch black color with zero head or carbonation. Aromas of big dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, coffee, char, toast, licorice, oak, clove, vanilla, and roasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good balance and complexity of roasted malt and oak barrel notes; with good strength. Taste of big dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, coffee, char, toast, licorice, molasses, oak, clove, vanilla, and roasted earthiness. Light roasted bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, coffee, char, toast, oak, vanilla, licorice, clove, molasses, and roasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Fantastic complexity and balance of dark/roasted malt and oak barrel flavors; with huge robustness and zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Zero carbonation and very full bodied; with a very creamy, slick, and moderately chalky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a light warming present after the finish. Overall this is a really excellent imperial stout, despite being flat. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roasted malt, licorice, and barrel flavors; and quite smooth to sip on for the big ABV. A very enjoyable offering. I will definitely try and get a carbonated bottle in the future.

Sample from bottle @sbwf13, vintage 2011. Near black with small brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, licorice, tar, ash, smoke and tobacco. Taste is a bit acidic, liquorice, roasted, coffee, licorice, tar, chocolate and earth. Very pleasant

Corked & Caged 750 ml Bottle. Pours dark as a subterraneous labyrinth with a solid layer of espresso foam. Aggressive notes of charred oak, mocha, licorice and bittersweet chocolate in the aroma. The flavor starts out heavy on the roasted malt, licorice and molasses closely followed by espresso, anise, vanilla, pine and whiskey. Mouthfeel is naturally thick and syrupy with low carbonation and a final assault of charred malt and booze in the finish. Overall, an extremely rich and roasty brew best enjoyed in small doses.
Bottle sampled at a tasting event. From notes. Roasty coffee and chocolate with a decent bit of dark fruit and caramel. Very good.

FROM NOTES: July 1, 12

A: Chocolate, vanilla, whiskey, oak, coffee, dark roasted malts, black licorice, a touch smoky, some alcohol. A strong nose on this beer.
A: Pours black with a one-finger brown head that quickly dissipates into a small ring and minimal lacing left behind.

O: A good buddy busted this out of his cellar for us to share, after I was already convinced that Uinta is a world class brewery. Black viscous pour a khaki head that coats the glass. Aroma is chocolate, wood, licorice, and caramel. Taste is about the same. Slick palate. Booze is completely concealed.

Black and thin. Weak aroma of licorice and wood. Smoothest beer Ive had @ 10%+ and at 13.2, this beer is a hell-damning sin in Utah. So its black gold in Texas. Walk slowly, limit your talking, and carry a small glass.

C&C trade bottle from 9-14-2011. Cork kinda limped out of the bottle but there was carbonation that made a nice looking pour reminiscent of a Guinness. Big chocolate aroma with a hint of spice and sweetness. Sweet flavor at first that finishes fairly dry with some dark malt, dark chocolate and espresso. Seriously, this is 13+ ABV? No clue how they hid it so well. Tasty.
Bottle..Pour is black with a dark tan head..Nose is licorice, spice, smoke, roast, alcohol, chocolate malts...Taste is chocolate, spices, roast, dark fruits, alcohol, licorice, rich
bottle, pours deep ruby black, tan thick head. nice porter malty alcohol nose. warm alcohol feel, coffee, roasted malt, brown sugar... yumm!

Bottle share at the Syb Pig. Small snifter. Pours a very black, oiyl pour. Aroma of dark chocolate, anise, prunes, and tobacco. Taste is similar with notes of chocolate nibs, tobacco, anise, prunes, and clove. Medium to heavy body. Some lacing. Oily palette with a clean, smooth finish. Excellent beer.
Bottle in Vegas at Ramseys. Poured thick black with decent tan head. Lace is impressive. Aroma of choc and slight booze. Drying bitter tingly taste. Good.

Tap - Barrel Aged Version: black pour with a small brown head. Aroma is molasses, caramel, light hint of bourbon, vanilla, and alcohol. Flavor has a candy syrup note, caramel, molasses, toffee, brown sugar, liquid smoke, a small amount of toasted wood, light bourbon, cola, and vanilla. A lot of flavor packed into this beer, nice sipping, and not overly boozy for such a big beer.
Black as night, strong! Awesome licorice and stout sweetness. Crazy label, crazy beer, try if you have the chance.

Bottle. Pours a beautiful motor oil black with a perfect mocha colored 2 finger head. Aroma is dark chocolate and oak. Taste is chocolate, roasted malt, molasses and a bourbony finish. Rich silky palate. This beer stands up to most of the more heralded beers of its ilk. Absolutely delicious.
7/15/2010. 750 ml. corked and caged bottle. Pours black with a beige head. Aromas of dark roasted malt, licorice, chocolate. Balanced and complex. Bitter finish. Awesome porter.
Bottle from Premiere. A bit much licorice and oak, a good imperial porter but not as much as a black beer, which it was mislabelled. Chocolate quality is good.Easy mouthfeel.
Black pour. Aroma of alcohol, chocolate, licorice and dark fruit. Flavor starts sweet, then blooms into a more complex blend of chocolate, fruit and, well, alcohol. Very smooth palate. great.

Black pour, small tan head that lingers. Aroma of primarily chocolate, light roast, light oak, some alcohol. Medium to fully body, dry with some alcohol. To be fair, its hidden really well for its content. Chocolate dominates with a touch of oak and roast. Lightly vinous at the end. Really nice.
bottle at Mr Goodbar. thick black pour , dark tan head. full bodied. dark chocolate, heavy roasted maltiness. full flavored beer. Big but very drinkable at 13%. very nice
Black...period. medium khaki head. Roasted malty aroma. Taste is coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate and caramel. Very thick mouthful, very good. Very impressed overall.

Pours motor oil black, no light escapes like a black hole. Aromas of burnt malt, caramel and licorice with notes of coffee. Flavors are very complex with coffee, burnt toast, malt, licorice, a bit of dark chocolate and a bit of alcohol burn, but that does not affect the taste at all. This is a delicious beer that you should try, no exceptions.

Pours thick and viscuous. The color of dark or black walnut. has an inkling of lighter hues but no light passes through. it merely suggests them with its deep body. Has a thin head of creamy mocha colored foam that refreshes with each turn of the glass. Alcohol legs and shimmering wet lace. 

Nose is roasted malt, toasted grain but nothing burnt until the drink. Theres a little coffee and some semi sweet chocolate. Dark fruits are too vague to name them but they are there. It has a soft rye on the nose that is a tad spicy but mellow. It has no alcohol on the nose and thats impressive. Theres a touch of vanilla and a little toffee. This does not smell terribly sweet. In fact it smells dry and a little bitter. 

Taste is expansive and full. Malt is velvety smooth and fat. Lots of toasted roasted grain but only a touch of burnt toast at the finish. Toffee and vanilla go so well together. The rye stays soft on the palate and mellow and adds its share of bitterness to a good coffee bitterness. Chocolate is smooth, deep and rich but not too sweet. As this drinks it starts to taste like whiskey. Has a ferocious abv that remains smooth on the palate and gives a nice warmth to the back palate and in the chest as it goes down. Finishes dry and a little slick. 

The rye really adds a depth to this. The mouthfeel is as good as ti gets for a big beer like this one. The abv is done to perfection. The fact that it is not terrible sweet lets the grain adn the dark flavors shine in a bold way. Exceptionally balanced and smooth.

Excellent licorice taste in the front. Nice coffee mocha taste in the end. Not too bitter great for the palate.

750 ml bottle corked and caged received in a Christmas in July Secret Santa trade. Pours a thick black with no head. The aroma is roasty and has a lot of molasses notes coming through. Taste is raisin and other dark fruits. Very roasty. Thick mouthfeel.

750ml, bottling date 4/18/11. Powerful and enticing aroma of dark, roasty malts, oak and dark chocolate, with notes of licorice, prune, black cherry, toffee, earthiness, faint vanilla, espresso and a touch of alcohol in the background. Solid ebony in color, rather thickly coats the glass, with a very fine, subsiding, light brown head. Flavor profile is rich and complex, roasty and bittersweet to start with plenty of of fine dark chocolate and charred oak, blending with a lasting dark, dried fruit character, caramel and licorice, and finishing with a light-moderate amount of bitterness, faint alcohol, old wood, earth and a certain lingering tartness. Viscous, substantial and warming on the palate with a massive body.  Feels every bit of its 13+% abv. but after this much time, the alcohol presence is really quite minimal, considering the substantial strength.  Pretty impressive, overall. Easy to see where the name comes from -- "It just keeps going on and on, forever..."

Bottle shared by my brother. Pour is a syrupy black, some tan fluffy head. Aroma is really woody, nice booziness to it. Not much black licorice but tons of roasted malts, nice bitter chocolate, great sipping beer.

Pours thick black with thick caramel head. Smells of alcohol, licorice, oak, roasted malts, and chocolate. Tastes of bitter, chocolate, alcohol, and malts. Coats the tongue and the flavor is nice and long. Very, very, very tasty beer.
Strong, chocolatey, sweet. Thick bodied. Dark, with modest cork colored head. A little much.

Aroma of dark fruit sweetness, chocolate, and roasted malts. Pours a hearty opaque black with a one-finger, mostly diminishing, khakie head and no lacing. The taste is a rewarding roasty sweetness. Satisfying round creamy mouthfeel. Overall, an exceptionally rich and complex beer. One to savor. Improves as it warms.

Tastes are black licorice, dark roasted coffee, dark chocolate, molasses, brown sugar, raisin, prune, and oak. Full bodied, syrupy texture, soft carbonation, and a moderate warmth in the finish. This beer has aged exceptionally well the flavors are well balanced, and while sweet it is not overtly so, making this a fantastic sipper.

Tasted at SIBF 2013. Black, dark tan head. Black is the right name -- SUPER dark roasted malts in here. Candi and brown sugar counter this very roasty brew. Covers the alcohol beautifully -- couldnt believe it was more than 13%.

AWESOME beer. A rich fruity aroma. Flavor is roasted fruity and very well balanced with both sweetness and bitterness and a licorice aftertaste. Mouthfeel is creamy and full. Color is pitch-black with a brown head.

On tap at Lunar Brewing Co.. Dispensed to a snifter with a black/brown hue, a modest amount of tan head foam that diminished quickly to a ring & film, and didnt leave much in the way of lacing. The nose was roasty, smooth malt, some tanniny wood & smoke hints, cocoa, and dark fruit sweetness. The taste was similar notes, plus a moderate hop bitterness that faded into the complexity. Softly carbonated, but rich and full bodied. Stayed smooth and warming even after sitting a considerable amount of time.

Very smooth, with a silky texture. Great and subtle notes with the licorice flavors coming thru. Good sipping ale, and goes well with cheese for sure. Very strong in alcohol but not overpowering in the least
Bottle to glass. HUGE tan head and dark black color. Very apparent char aftertaste and hints of coffee and licorice. Quite tasty.

Sampled at esbls. Black with no head. Really nice fruit and licorice in the aroma. A roasted flavor with big alcohol, dark fruit and more complex fruit. Big malts. This is good stuff but that ABV is a bit much.
On tap at Unos Hamilton during Philly Beer Week. Nice beer. Very Strong. Alcohol apparent. Complex, woody, with a mellow roast flavor.
Nog får man hålla med om att det här är en bra pjäs. Fat kan anas. Skulle gissa på bourbon. Champinjon. Vanilj. Fokuserar inte så noga, njuter mest

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2014 Big tan head. Aroma of rye spice, licorice, chocolate, wheat, and booze. Tastes of char, sour lactic, wood, with a big dose of alcohol that rushes to the front. Bottle: pours dark black with a thick tan head, aroma of oak and chocolate, taste is malty, chocolate, not too sweet though, a little of the black licorice and warming in the finish. Very nice.

Bottle into glass. brown black appearance with a hearty thick brown head that leaves lots of lacing. beautiful beer. nose is coffee and toasted malts and mocha. Really nice long bitter finish.

I really, really enjoyed this one. Its fun to discover a beer that youve seen sitting on the shelf for months, passing it by time after time and then finally trying it and getting blown away. I tasted it on draft at Good Karma in San Jose (highly recommended). It pours a very dark brown color with a huge brown head. The aroma has some licorice, fudge, spicy wood and a hint of whiskey. The flavor is very rich and toasty with dark chocolate syrup, wood and a hint of whiskey. Just a really fine beer. Looking forward to picking up a bottle and trying it again!

25.6 oz corked bottle, what is that, 75cl? Purchased from Cardinal in Niles with a "bottled on 12 <unreadable> 10 date" - whatever that is- and cellar aged almost a year. Enjoyed out on the patio as a Fathers Day treat. Pours a thick vicious black with no initial head, then a long lasting cafe au lait one leaving drippy lacing. A bit intimidating.Aroma has chocolate, rich espresso, plenty of roasted malt, some soy and some grape. The initial taste is of bakers chocolate, soy and molasses, with thick caramelly malts. Then after a bit the espresso kicks in, thick and bitter, with the sweetness of the molasses and caramel hanging in underneath. Full bodied and syrupy. Some alcohol present in the body, but more indirectly felt afterward. Finishes chocolatey/espresso-y bitter with underlying sweetness. Wow! Not sure what style they were going for, and perhaps it is too sweet (faintly) for an imp stout, but this would be up high with the taste and depth, if perhaps not super complex. Been a Uinta fan, and this is their best. Kudos!
Deep dark and carmel. Snooth and slight botter. Like what a guinesd dreams it should be.

Bottle.  Pours an extremely dark black body with a tight bubbled dark brown head that faded to a thin covering. Heavy chocolate and licorice flavors mix with the oakiness, rounding out with some alcohol heat.  Thick, chewy, and full bodied with minimal soft carbonation.  Pretty decent, I was expecting much worse because of the high alcohol, but its actually decently drinkable.

In short: A monster black beer offering good complexity and relatively good drinkability.  Very good.
How: Bottle 750ml, corked & caged.  Consumed when probably one year of age or so.
The look: Black body topped by a very small tan head.
In long: Nose is big rich roasted malts, a strong woody sensation that resembles barrels (although Im almost 100% certain this beer has no barrel treatment).  Taste is rich roasted grainy cereals, all-grain brown bread, high-cacao content black chocolate, fudge, roasted almonds & nuts, black coffee, a bit of tar, a surprising herbal hops presence.  Very full body that doesnt feel too heavy because of a generous carbonation.  I dont know if it is because I let it sit in my cellar for a year but this beer was a lot less hot and aggressive than expected, this 13.2% monster beer was relatively easy to drink, I didnt feel the strength of the beer while drinking it, I only felt it after I went through the entire 750ml.  A good effort from a brewery that usually doesnt do it for me.  And what a strange coincidence, after a few bottles of Labyrinth I couldnt find my way out of the house, missed a family dinner, really, wife was a lot less impress by the Labyrinth coincidence and says I was just passed out, whatever.

Midnight black pour with a smallish dusky tan head. Sweetish/roasty nose of deep, dark chocolate, stewed fruit/Swiss chard, and toasted oak.

I can see why Uinta called this a black ale, and not an imperial stout, but it could certainly pass for one, and, in fact, Id like to think of it as such, because it has the wonderful fruity aspects that were intrinsic to the 19th century examples Ive read about, and which are all but absinthe from todays interpretations of the style.

This is a truly luxurious sipper, and a definite winner...all the more surprising to me coming from Utah.
Bottled sample.  This was a very rich dark beer.  Nice chocolate flavour with a nice hops taste.  Loved this one

750ml bottle - $12.99 at Olde Crabapple Bottle Shoppe in Alpharetta, Georgia. Bottled on: 06/08/11. The removal of the cork was one of the most difficult Ive come across, so, ultimately a classy-looking but obnoxious packaging. Usually one worries about getting out of a labyrinth, I was concerned Id never get in.

Appearance: Pours out a matte black, inky-looking body with a slow-growing, slow-receding, tan head. After the workout with the cork, I sure could use a beer!

Smell: Somewhat sweetish, roasty nose with a backdrop of wooden barrels, hunks from an oversized chocolate bar, and lighter, though not insubstantial notes of caramel, stewed fruit, and vanilla candy.

Taste: Bittersweet chocolate ganache, homemade caramel sauce, vanilla sugar, smooth espresso produced by an above-average barista, and, already, plenty of the licorice. Soundly sweet, but not overly so, though theres a noted richness about almost everything in the taste. Fruity accents of sweetish cherry and plums -- some sips its fairly tapered, others, its more pronounced and long enduring. Mildly tannic, mildly spicy barrel character. Only modesty warming on the relatively sweetish finish that fluctuatingly allows for the fruit, choco-licorice, or roastiness to lingering into the aftertaste.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied. Medium-light carbonation. Smooth, chewy mouthfeel.

Overall: Why, its like an imperialized, barrel-aged Kalamazoo! Some beers, right from that first sip, you think "oh Jesus what have I gotten into this time" as waves of disappointment and abject weariness wash over you. You may even stick it out like a trooper, perhaps wanting to get your moneys worth and/or hoping like a fool for a miraculous turnaround that never comes. Thankfully, this one was just a treat from sip one until the bottle had been drained and a nap was desired.
